Bitcoin could be worth over $1 million p.video_name: Bitcoin could be worth over $1 million per coin in the next few years, says Fundstrat's Tom Lee [KR8EZo5IesE]
Bitcoin could be worth over $1 million p.full_text: Joining us now, Tom Leaf, Fundstrat, Global Advisors, Head of Research, probably not coming as a big surprise to you, Tom, you've been saying similar things, but one of the things you're emphasizing today, the most hated V-shape bounce in history, or at least in your young, but getting older, life. Yes, that's right. I think many people, when April happened and we had Terra Farmageddon and the market went into a free fall, investors liquidated because they thought we were entering a recession. And as you guys had covered, the market then staged a V-shaped recovery, which caught many people off guard because they wanted to have a chance to get in. They wanted the stock market to be like a K-shaped or flat line. Instead, it was a V-shaped bounce. And so most investors are underexposed at the moment, and they're trying to look at headlines with a half-empty view. But as you guys know, earnings have actually been really resilient, and I think it tells a very good story. Yeah, Dow's not, hasn't been hitting, it has hit a new high, but it hasn't in the recent session. But S&P and NASDAQ continue to do pretty well. So there is also a perception, Tom, that valuations have returned to levels that have people worried. And you are citing an equity-weighted S&P multiple. Explain that. Of what? What's the equity-weighted multiple right now? Yeah, what we're saying is, instead of someone saying, oh, the MAG is making the market expensive, let's just take the average P.E. of the S&P of every stock. And it was around 17.6 times in 2019. Now we've had six, what I call extinction-like events, you know, COVID, the bullwhip supply chain effect, inflation surge fed fastest hikes, Trump tariffs, and then, of course, U.S. bombing Iran. Six of them, yeah, okay. Yeah, all of them should have wiped out earnings, but the S&P earnings have grown, and yet the equal-weight P.E. is now 16 times. So the market's gotten cheaper in the last six years, despite proving they can grow earnings through six extinction-level events. You know, the MAG 7, though, there was a journal article that says there's a real split between the MAG 7, those that are really doing well from AI and those that aren't. And if you look at the stock performances, I think Apple's down something like 16 or 18 percent over the last year, while you have Microsoft and others that have really taken off. Do you think the MAG 7 stays together, or do we need a new terminology, a new grouping for leadership in the markets? I mean, to me, the MAG 7 have become household names. You know, like, Apple is Apple, and Google is Google, and we know the product, and we know the stock. And I think they have really established themselves as consumer and business companies. And for me, Apple has been sort of quietly ready to pounce on AI, but I don't think they need to pay up for any of these models. So I think Apple is going to surprise people. That's interesting. That's a contrarian viewpoint. People think Apple either is too far behind or just isn't going to be able to get the talent. It's losing talent, not getting it. Yeah. I mean, they didn't launch an iPhone until 2007, and mobile phones had been around for 15 years. But when they did enter that market, they completely transformed the marketplace. So to me, I think when they want to play big in AI, and when they do in that moment, I think they will change the game. Well, so the question, though, is do you think that historically, they've been able to do that because it's been a hardware game, largely, and a bit of software. I don't want to say software is not a huge part of it. But the question is whether you think the LLMs have become so advanced that to get there, you actually have to buy somebody else to do it, or you can actually catch up. I mean, that's the fundamental question underneath all of this. Yeah. And it's also possible that LLMs all get so good that they are about the same. Right. And then Apple gets commoditized. Correct. And so that Apple comes in and says, look, we have our safety. Look, we're known for our safety rails, protecting your privacy, optimizing what you want to do to make your life better. And they might come out with a version that really makes heads spin. So I think that I'm not ruling out Apple just because they're a little late. What do you make, by the way? There's some speculation over the weekend, some reports about a true the first real Apple foldable phone this fall. Would you would you buy a foldable phone? Yeah, I mean, I'm big market in China, by the way. People in China seem to love foldable phones. I think what I found is when when you offer someone a bigger screen size, you're pushing them more towards computing and something much higher capability. And with AI, we might want some of that augmented kind of reality. So maybe the time is right for a foldable phone. And again, I just want we got a minute left after last week in the genius act. And you suddenly are I don't know whether you're I look at you as as Mr. Equity guru or crypto guru. Are you able to do both? You have been you're going to continue this. Yes. You know, clients know my goal is to make them find them good ideas and and make them money. And now I want to do that with with shareholders. You know, my I'm dedicated to delivering a great return for anyone who invests in any of our ideas, including whether it was our granny shots, which is outperforming year to date and almost one point nine billion of AOM after eight months. And now with Bitmine, I am dedicated to really making this one of the best performing stocks. And people need we don't have time to go into exactly how that works. But but here we are. One twenty basically on on Bitcoin, which you used to say at 70. And, you know, that that was a 60 percent move or something that you were. Yeah. Forecasting is within the next couple of months or at least this year. Here we are now. What, 150? I think the two hundred to two hundred fifty thousand for Bitcoin still makes sense because that would still only value it at 25 percent of the size of the gold market. So I think digital gold means Bitcoin should be worth over a million per Bitcoin. And it could happen in the next few years. But maybe pricing 25 percent of that, especially with Genius Act, makes sense. Are you going to, I don't know, start making comments and recommendations about stable coins? Yes. I mean, in a sense, stable coins are the chat moment for crypto because businesses like it and consumers are adopting it. And now we see JP Morgan and Citi and getting into the stable coin market and the genius act. Of course, you play that. Well, Circle is one way because it is, you know, a standout company. They've done really well. But Ethereum is really the way to play stable coins because the majority of stable coins are created on Ethereum. It's over 30 percent of its network fees. And if Scott Besson's right in it, he says now it's close to a Fort Troy market. That's exponential growth for Ethereum. Ether has taken off. It was down at seventeen hundred or something like a month ago or two. Yes. Now it's back almost 36 or something. That's right. And I know Mark Newton, our head of technicals, thinks it's five thousand doable near term. But if you value it similar to Circle, it's over it's more between ten and twenty thousand. You give a rat's patootie about August 1st. Does anything change with that for you? Well, I knew. Yes, that's what you're going to. That's your answer. Well, it's a good one. Yeah. I mean, I think that on a half full, the tariffs are really good for the budget. So in companies are managing through these now and they're pretty significant now. And it's not inflation. They're not talking about as inflation. So that's the half full. But you're right. Maybe August 1st gets pushed again. And that would also be positive.

Samson Mow on Why the Bitcoin Bull Run ＂.video_name: Samson Mow on Why the Bitcoin Bull Run ＂Hasn’t Even Begun Yet＂ [DByVWY_br7Q]
Samson Mow on Why the Bitcoin Bull Run ＂.full_text: It's kind of depressing to see alts run because that usually brings us back down as a whole. The last Bitcoin rally seems to be running out of steam and now altcoins are stealing the spotlight. But for Bitcoin maximalist Samson Mao, that's just noise. According to him, the real bull market hasn't even started yet. The bull market has legs and I think we can go probably anywhere up to 500,000 to a million in the next 12 months. In this interview, we sat down with Samson to explore Bitcoin's potential for the second half of 2025 and why he believes the best is still to come. Before we get started, as usual, this video is not financial advice, just educational content. Do your own research before investing in crypto. I'm Giovanni. Let's get started. I saw a statement that you put out on Twitter where you were saying that this is just the start of this bull run. This is a pretty bold statement. How would you back it up? Well, if you break down the inflation rate, the real inflation rate, and you peg it to something real like eggs, you get 11 percent annually. So if you apply that to the previous all time high in 2021, that takes us to somewhere around 100, 101 K. So, you know, that's kind of the floor. That's just keeping up with inflation. That's Bitcoin just keeping up with inflation. So 120 K, 130 K, that means you're beating inflation by 20 percent over a four year period or 30 percent over a four year period, which is not really spectacular. So I think we have a lot of room to run. The bull market has legs and I think we can go probably anywhere up to 500,000 to a million in the next 12 months, because this is also a delayed market movement, too. If you think about it, we should have ran already. We should already have been at 200,000 a coin and we're still at 120. It seems that you are expecting Bitcoin just by default to do great things. Why do you think that the 200 K benchmark is more of an adequate one compared to where we are now? Well, it has to do with all the adoption happening in the world today. You have countries adopting Bitcoin. You have the ETFs, which are just taking in a massive amount of capital and eliminate the bottleneck for moving capital into Bitcoin from legacy markets. There is no more barrier. And then you have companies like Strategy and now Blockstream that are also moving into the treasury space. And Strategy alone has accumulated 600,000 plus Bitcoin. So, you know, just like doing a quick back of the napkin math, it just doesn't seem possible that we are still hovering around inflation adjusted Bitcoin all time highs from four years ago at 100 to 120,000. We should be well over 200,000 just by my approximate estimate. We see that there are also other catalysts. The first one is the Genius Act regarding stable coins. A lot of people are particularly bullish on the Genius Act because it has the potential to integrate the stable coins into the U.S. economy. What is your view on this and its potential impact on Bitcoin and the crypto markets in general? Well, I think this has a lot less to do with Bitcoin than just the markets in general for the U.S. So the Genius Act, it adds clarity, but I don't think it changes fundamentally anything about Bitcoin. It gives a better structure and guidance on stable coin issuers. And that is good for stable coin issuers. But even without that, I see stable coins continuing to grow. This is just the U.S. government becoming more comfortable with the idea of stable coins. And the fact that stable coins like Tether are just taking up a massive amount of treasury buys and holdings equivalent to countries. I think Tether is ranked somewhere in the top 20 now of all holders of UST bills. The fact is, Bitcoin and stable coins are now integrated into the U.S. economy permanently and in a very deep way. I think what is interesting for Bitcoin is, one, the audit of Fort Knox, as we've been promised. And two, passing of the Bitcoin Act from Cynthia Lummis that would allow the U.S. to actively accumulate Bitcoin. Now, there's a bit of other interesting news that came out today, which was a reporter filed some freedom of information requests and found that the U.S. marshals only have about 28,000 Bitcoin now, I believe. And that's a lot less than was expected. So I think these bills currently in motion or on the table are missing the bigger picture. The bigger picture is that the U.S. needs to accumulate Bitcoin very, very rapidly if it wants to have a significant Bitcoin reserve treasury. So the window is closing. And I'm not sure they really realize that yet now, because if they did, they would be talking about the Bitcoin Act, not these other bills. I know that you are, of course, a Bitcoin maximalist, but I'm just looking at a lot of chats on Axe about an altcoin season coming up because we saw the Ethereum price going up and the Bitcoin dominance decreasing. What do you think? Is it an inversion of the trend we have seen in the past months? It's kind of depressing to see alts run because that usually brings us back down as a whole. So Bitcoin rises and then the people that are investing in altcoins make some money and then they pump their coins. Right. So it's always a cycle. Bitcoin goes up, it leads the pack, and then you see alts run a bit and then things come back down and all the investors and altcoins get liquidated or they blow up somehow or something happens and then Bitcoin comes down along with it a little bit and then we go back up. But the cycle rinses and repeats over and over and over. I don't really worry too much about the alts because they're all very small cap, small cap coins. And compared to Bitcoin, it doesn't really matter. They can easily manipulate the floats and move their prices and they can drive their prices through direct announcements like Ripple trying to do business. Right. Like what is Ripple? It's a company now, but it has a crypto coin. But in real world, that should technically be a stock or a security. But here we are. But I'm not really worried about that. I think in the long run, Bitcoin dominance will continue to increase. And I think this might be the final alt season if there is one. But it doesn't look very promising. Let's talk about another catalyst that is moving this market, which is the continued purchase of Bitcoin from Bitcoin treasury companies. Some analysts are saying that the next crypto bear market will be triggered by some of these companies going belly up and essentially create a ripple effect similar to the ones we saw in previous crashes, like in 2022 with other major players in the industry. Do you see such a risk as a possibility? It's definitely a concern, especially with altcoin treasury companies. I don't see it ending well for any company that is taking Ethereum or Solana or anything as a reserve asset. I think those will end up very badly in the long run. And I don't know if that will have a cascading impact on Bitcoin. I see if there is a big run up and a drawdown, like similar to previous cycles, that some of the Bitcoin treasury companies, the smaller ones, might fold, especially if their CEOs don't understand what it is that they're holding. I see it less as a risk with micro strategy or strategy rather, because Saylor has proved himself through one of the biggest bear markets that we've had in recent years, and he's held and he's kept on accumulating. The newer entrants, it's unsure whether they have the fortitude to survive a drawdown. I think many of them are just copying, trying to fast follow strategy. And, you know, that's definitely a red flag in my view. So I would say the bigger ones, or at least companies like Blockstream, helmed by Adam Back, are less risky because you know, Adam understands Bitcoin to the fullest extent possible. And that means it's a safer investment. But the smaller ones, I would definitely say no. And definitely altcoin treasury companies, I wouldn't touch those with a hundred foot pole. So states buying Bitcoin for their reserves, we've been advising several governments in the world regarding this, but we still don't see many examples all over the world. So what do you think is the main challenge for the average government to come on board with something like that? The biggest challenge for most governments and nation-state adoption in general is just red tape. It takes a lot of effort to get something done. And not every country has a central leader that can just pass a law. There's a lot of deliberation, discussion. And you see this again in the US, right? Like it's a very chaotic, fragmented procedure to get anything passed. And this is the biggest barrier, I think, to nation-state adoption. We've tried a lot at GEN3 to try to follow the top-down approach and engage the governments to educate them and see if they will pass some laws. But we've shifted our strategy a bit since then to take smaller projects like sandbox projects or creating special economic zones or rolling out some prototype kind of test projects, if you will. And I think this is probably more pragmatic because that gets them into the Bitcoin game at a much smaller scale and a scale which they're comfortable with. I think getting a country to make Bitcoin legal tender is much harder and far longer a path to adoption than people expect. Some people are saying that with this pace, in a few years, these companies will hold the majority of all available Bitcoin. There will be very little left for ordinary people, people that perhaps the so-called unbanked people in the third world countries that should benefit the most from this technology to purchase Bitcoin cheap. So don't you think that this process is a little bit going against the democratization of Bitcoin? Well, you could think that for sure, that all the corporations will get all the Bitcoin or nation-states will get all the Bitcoin. Now, is it actually possible that billions of people around the world get physical Bitcoin that they themselves hold and front run the massive financial industrial complex? I'm really not sure because the biggest barrier to people adopting Bitcoin is themselves and not understanding Bitcoin. And I think price is definitely a factor that makes people want to have Bitcoin. So people want Bitcoin at 0.12 million or 0.2 million or 0.5 million, but they don't want Bitcoin when it drops to 0.08 or 0.09. So this is just the way it's been and the way it always will be. People will just get Bitcoin at higher and higher prices and there will just be less and less Bitcoin available for them because of all these other actors scooping up all available coins. Now, that's not to say we can't do anything about it. And Gen3's other initiative is Aqua and trying to onboard the next billion people into Bitcoin. So I think there are groups like us that are actively trying to get more people on board. This has been mostly a bull run driven by institutions and very little involvement from retail. But maybe now I'm seeing that Bitcoin is being talked about a lot in the mainstream press. Do you expect now a wave of retail investors suddenly waking up to this new rally? No, I think this is not yet the rally. I think they'll start waking up at 0.2 million or 200,000 a coin. I would say retail is still sleeping on this. And anecdotally, most people I know have said their friends and family are not reaching out to them yet to ask about Bitcoin. So we're not even close to peak retail awareness or retail mania. But, you know, once you cross that next cognitive threshold of 0.2M, that's when people think, OK, I'm missing out and I need to get this. And that's when they start piling in. Last time we talked in November last year, you were predicting that 2025 was going to be the year of one million dollars for Bitcoin. Do you still stand by that prediction? I still do, but it seems like we're not close to it yet. We still need to do like a 8x from here to get one million. So maybe 2026. But I don't discount the possibility that we can have a very rapid run up in the next six months if all factors line up and you do have retail coming on board. Samson, thanks a lot for the conversation. Yeah, thanks Giovanni. It's been fun.

segments.text: It's kind of depressing to see alts run because that usually brings us back down as a whole.
The last Bitcoin rally seems to be running out of steam and now altcoins are stealing the spotlight.
But for Bitcoin maximalist Samson Mao, that's just noise.
According to him, the real bull market hasn't even started yet.
The bull market has legs and I think we can go probably anywhere up to 500,000 to a million in the next 12 months.
In this interview, we sat down with Samson to explore Bitcoin's potential for the second half of 2025 and why he believes the best is still to come.
Before we get started, as usual, this video is not financial advice, just educational content.
Do your own research before investing in crypto.
I'm Giovanni. Let's get started.
I saw a statement that you put out on Twitter where you were saying that this is just the start of this bull run.
This is a pretty bold statement.
How would you back it up?
Well, if you break down the inflation rate, the real inflation rate, and you peg it to something real like eggs, you get 11 percent annually.
So if you apply that to the previous all time high in 2021, that takes us to somewhere around 100, 101 K.
So, you know, that's kind of the floor.
That's just keeping up with inflation.
That's Bitcoin just keeping up with inflation.
So 120 K, 130 K, that means you're beating inflation by 20 percent over a four year period or 30 percent over a four year period, which is not really spectacular.
So I think we have a lot of room to run.
The bull market has legs and I think we can go probably anywhere up to 500,000 to a million in the next 12 months, because this is also a delayed market movement, too.
If you think about it, we should have ran already.
We should already have been at 200,000 a coin and we're still at 120.
It seems that you are expecting Bitcoin just by default to do great things.
Why do you think that the 200 K benchmark is more of an adequate one compared to where we are now?
Well, it has to do with all the adoption happening in the world today.
You have countries adopting Bitcoin.
You have the ETFs, which are just taking in a massive amount of capital and eliminate the bottleneck for moving capital into Bitcoin from legacy markets.
There is no more barrier.
And then you have companies like Strategy and now Blockstream that are also moving into the treasury space.
And Strategy alone has accumulated 600,000 plus Bitcoin.

So, you know, just like doing a quick back of the napkin math, it just doesn't seem possible that we are still hovering around inflation adjusted Bitcoin all time highs from four years ago at 100 to 120,000.
We should be well over 200,000 just by my approximate estimate.
We see that there are also other catalysts.
The first one is the Genius Act regarding stable coins.
A lot of people are particularly bullish on the Genius Act because it has the potential to integrate the stable coins into the U.S. economy.
What is your view on this and its potential impact on Bitcoin and the crypto markets in general?
Well, I think this has a lot less to do with Bitcoin than just the markets in general for the U.S.
So the Genius Act, it adds clarity, but I don't think it changes fundamentally anything about Bitcoin.
It gives a better structure and guidance on stable coin issuers.
And that is good for stable coin issuers.
But even without that, I see stable coins continuing to grow.
This is just the U.S.
government becoming more comfortable with the idea of stable coins.
And the fact that stable coins like Tether are just taking up a massive amount of treasury buys and holdings equivalent to countries.
I think Tether is ranked somewhere in the top 20 now of all holders of UST bills.
The fact is, Bitcoin and stable coins are now integrated into the U.S.
economy permanently and in a very deep way.
I think what is interesting for Bitcoin is, one, the audit of Fort Knox, as we've been promised.
And two, passing of the Bitcoin Act from Cynthia Lummis that would allow the U.S.
to actively accumulate Bitcoin.
Now, there's a bit of other interesting news that came out today, which was a reporter filed some freedom of information requests and found that the U.S.
marshals only have about 28,000 Bitcoin now, I believe.
And that's a lot less than was expected.
So I think these bills currently in motion or on the table are missing the bigger picture.
The bigger picture is that the U.S.
needs to accumulate Bitcoin very, very rapidly if it wants to have a significant Bitcoin reserve treasury.
So the window is closing.
And I'm not sure they really realize that yet now, because if they did, they would be talking about the Bitcoin Act, not these other bills.
I know that you are, of course, a Bitcoin maximalist, but I'm just looking at a lot of chats on Axe about an altcoin season coming up because we saw the
Ethereum price going up and the Bitcoin dominance decreasing.
What do you think? Is it an inversion of the trend we have seen in the past months?
It's kind of depressing to see alts run because that usually brings us back down as a whole.
So Bitcoin rises and then the people that are investing in altcoins make some money and then they pump their coins.
Right. So it's always a cycle.
Bitcoin goes up, it leads the pack, and then you see alts run a bit and then things come back down and all the investors and altcoins get liquidated or they blow up
somehow or something happens and then Bitcoin comes down along with it a little bit and then we go back up.
But the cycle rinses and repeats over and over and over.
I don't really worry too much about the alts because they're all very small cap, small cap coins.
And compared to Bitcoin, it doesn't really matter.
They can easily manipulate the floats and move their prices and they can drive their prices through direct announcements like Ripple trying to do business.
Right. Like what is Ripple?
It's a company now, but it has a crypto coin.
But in real world, that should technically be a stock or a security.
But here we are.
But I'm not really worried about that.
I think in the long run, Bitcoin dominance will continue to increase.
And I think this might be the final alt season if there is one.
But it doesn't look very promising.
Let's talk about another catalyst that is moving this market, which is the continued purchase of Bitcoin from Bitcoin treasury companies.

Some analysts are saying that the next crypto bear market will be triggered by some of these companies going belly up and essentially create a ripple effect similar to the ones we saw in previous crashes,
like in 2022 with other major players in the industry.
Do you see such a risk as a possibility?
It's definitely a concern, especially with altcoin treasury companies.
I don't see it ending well for any company that is taking Ethereum or Solana or anything as a reserve asset.
I think those will end up very badly in the long run.
And I don't know if that will have a cascading impact on Bitcoin.

I see if there is a big run up and a drawdown, like similar to previous cycles, that some of the Bitcoin treasury companies, the smaller ones, might fold, especially if their CEOs don't understand what it is that they're holding.

I see it less as a risk with micro strategy or strategy rather, because Saylor has proved himself through one of the biggest bear markets that we've had in recent years, and he's held and he's kept on accumulating.
The newer entrants, it's unsure whether they have the fortitude to survive a drawdown.
I think many of them are just copying, trying to fast follow strategy.
And, you know, that's definitely a red flag in my view.
So I would say the bigger ones, or at least companies like Blockstream, helmed by Adam Back, are less risky because you know, Adam understands Bitcoin to the fullest extent possible.
And that means it's a safer investment.
But the smaller ones, I would definitely say no.
And definitely altcoin treasury companies, I wouldn't touch those with a hundred foot pole.
So states buying Bitcoin for their reserves, we've been advising several governments in the world regarding this, but we still don't see many examples all over the world.
So what do you think is the main challenge for the average government to come on board with something like that?
The biggest challenge for most governments and nation-state adoption in general is just red tape.
It takes a lot of effort to get something done.
And not every country has a central leader that can just pass a law.
There's a lot of deliberation, discussion.
And you see this again in the US, right?
Like it's a very chaotic, fragmented procedure to get anything passed.
And this is the biggest barrier, I think, to nation-state adoption.
We've tried a lot at GEN3 to try to follow the top-down approach and engage the governments to educate them and see if they will pass some laws.
But we've shifted our strategy a bit since then to take smaller projects like sandbox projects or creating special economic zones or rolling out some prototype kind of test projects, if you will.
And I think this is probably more pragmatic because that gets them into the Bitcoin game at a much smaller scale and a scale which they're comfortable with.
I think getting a country to make Bitcoin legal tender is much harder and far longer a path to adoption than people expect.
Some people are saying that with this pace, in a few years, these companies will hold the majority of all available Bitcoin.

There will be very little left for ordinary people, people that perhaps the so-called unbanked people in the third world countries that should benefit the most from this technology to purchase Bitcoin cheap.
So don't you think that this process is a little bit going against the democratization of Bitcoin?
Well, you could think that for sure, that all the corporations will get all the Bitcoin or nation-states will get all the Bitcoin.
Now, is it actually possible that billions of people around the world get physical Bitcoin that they themselves hold and front run the massive financial industrial complex?
I'm really not sure because the biggest barrier to people adopting Bitcoin is themselves and not understanding Bitcoin.
And I think price is definitely a factor that makes people want to have Bitcoin.
So people want Bitcoin at 0.12 million or 0.2 million or 0.5 million, but they don't want Bitcoin when it drops to 0.08 or 0.09.
So this is just the way it's been and the way it always will be.
People will just get Bitcoin at higher and higher prices and there will just be less and less Bitcoin available for them because of all these other actors scooping up all available coins.
Now, that's not to say we can't do anything about it.
And Gen3's other initiative is Aqua and trying to onboard the next billion people into Bitcoin.
So I think there are groups like us that are actively trying to get more people on board.
This has been mostly a bull run driven by institutions and very little involvement from retail.
But maybe now I'm seeing that Bitcoin is being talked about a lot in the mainstream press.
Do you expect now a wave of retail investors suddenly waking up to this new rally?
No, I think this is not yet the rally.
I think they'll start waking up at 0.2 million or 200,000 a coin.
I would say retail is still sleeping on this.
And anecdotally, most people I know have said their friends and family are not reaching out to them yet to ask about Bitcoin.
So we're not even close to peak retail awareness or retail mania.
But, you know, once you cross that next cognitive threshold of 0.2M, that's when people think, OK, I'm missing out and I need to get this.
And that's when they start piling in.
Last time we talked in November last year, you were predicting that 2025 was going to be the year of one million dollars for Bitcoin.
Do you still stand by that prediction?
I still do, but it seems like we're not close to it yet.
We still need to do like a 8x from here to get one million.
So maybe 2026.
But I don't discount the possibility that we can have a very rapid run up in the next six months if all factors line up and you do have retail coming on board.
Samson, thanks a lot for the conversation.
Yeah, thanks Giovanni.
It's been fun.

Maybe it's positioning a la Dan Niles. A lot of these pods that were long this stock coming in. I'm not sure. How often have I sat here talking with Carl and Jim every day about fixed wireless and the additions? We saw it with T-Mobile's quarter. We saw it with AT&T unexpectedly, given how much they're focused on fiber. But they added two hundred thousand of fixed wireless subs. We've seen it as well with Verizon. It's taking a toll. Actually, not that bad in terms of where things stand there. But not to mention the big, beautiful bill, which is reducing their tax bill at Charter, but is also reducing the tax bills of their competitors, namely the likes of AT&T. And what are they doing with that money? They're accelerating their build out of fiber that is competing against Charter. And so, well, I guess a lot of questions right now in terms of their ability to get back to adding subscribers, the broadband subscribers that are so important to its business. You can see Altice as well, which has an enormous amount of debt and a very small market cap also getting hit. I only ask because we got a downgrade of Procter today, largely from JP Morgan, sort of looking at challenges in the lower cohort. It may be. I mean, you know, also there was the affordable connectivity plan or program that under the Biden administration that went away and that for particularly for that cohort. And that impacted a lot of these numbers previously. But that's kind of gone now. So you may be right. It may simply be an affordability issue to a certain extent. I should, by the way, say that now Charter did say when they for the year ago quarter the impact from the loss of the ACP was only 50,000 subs, not the 100,000 they previously told us. But none of it looks particularly good right now.
